newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Avmin still committed to Zambia copper.
newsitem.headline: Avmin still committed to Zambia copper.

text.p: A consortium led by South African Avmin Ltd is still committed to spending over $1 billion on Zambia's copper crown jewels despite reports of a deadlock in talks with the Lusaka government, officials said.
Zambia's The Post newspaper reported on Wednesday that the Kafue consortium and the Zambian government had reached an impasse.
The report said the government was considering further splitting up the package of Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines Ltd assets the consortium submitted a bid for.

The Avmin consortium, including Phelps Dodge Corp, Noranda Inc and the Commonwealth Development Corp, bid for the Nchanga and Nkana divisions of ZCCM -- the state-owned mining company's prize assets accounting for almost half of its output.
Avmin spokesman Julian Gwillim said on Thursday the consortium had not been formally informed that the government was in the process of restructuring the ZCCM package.
"We are still committed to Zambia and of course the rebirth of those copper assets," he added.

Industry officials said the consortium remained committed to spending more than a billion dollars in Zambia, some $750 million on capital expenditure and the rest on debt assumption and social upliftment.
"That is serious money by any standards and signifies their commitment to the success of the whole thing," said one official who asked not to be named.

The Post quoted a Zambia Mines Ministry official as saying the package for which the consortium submitted a bid was too large and it would have been better to have smaller units to widen the investment base.
"If this deal falls through, we have no option but to unbundle the package and make it more accessible to potential investors," the ministry official said.

The Nchanga and Nkana divisions of ZCCM produced 225,000 tonnes of copper in the last financial year. The divisions include several open pit and underground copper mines, a copper tailings treatment plant, a cobalt treatment plant and smelter.
Avmin has already won the right to develop Zambia's Konkola North deposit, one of the deposits on which the country's flagging copper mining industry is pinning its hope for long-term survival.

A consortium led by Zambia Copper Investment Ltd -- 50.6 percent owned by Anglo American Corp of South Africa Ltd -- signed a memorandum of understanding with the Zambian government in February to develop the Konkola Deep mine.
A due diligence study into the project should be completed by the end of the year, Anglo said in June.
Analysts see the Zambian mining industry reviving after privatisation with production of copper surging to more than a million tonnes a year from current levels of around 400,000 tonnes.
